tabs.header_iregular:
Let's figure out the best way to take care of this period pain.

The approach would be to use an anti inflammatory pain reliever to not only reduce the pain, but reduce the amount of bleeding.

It is always better to take the pills day before the period starts to prevent the pain from building up.

With this approach in mind, see what is recommended below.

collapsable.title: Relieving Pain click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): 

Start taking this the day before your period  starts, and continue for the first few days of the period.

Take the tablets regularly, for 2-3 days each period, rather than 'now and then' when pain builds up (taking as-needed use is not adequate for most people).    

If taken early and in prescription strength (see "know this" for dosing), they are extremely successful in alleviating menstrual pain.

A good example is ibuprofen, naproxen, aspirin.

 

Can't take NSAIDS?    

Take a combination pill of Acetaminophen 500 mg (Pain reliever), Pamabrom 25mg (diuretic), Pyrilamine maleate 15 mg (antihistamine), Caffeine.    

Examples are Midol速, Pamprin速, Premsyn PMS.   

These are useful if you experience significant bloating, headache and water retention.    

Take midol速 if the main thing is a headache.

Take Pamprin速 if the main concern is feeling bloated.

collapsable.title: Bloated? headaches? click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Midol if mainly headaches.

Pamprin if mainly bloating.

collapsable.title: Worth trying click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Apply a heating pad to your lower belly area, below the belly button.
     
  • Take warm showers or baths.
     
  • Keep your legs raised while lying down.
     
  • Lie on the side with your knees bent.
     
  • Do light circular massage with your fingertips around your lower belly area.
     
  • Do low-fat vegetarian diet at least for now.
     
  • Cut back on salt to help prevent water retention.

    Water retention can lead to breast tenderness; swelling of your feet, ankles, and hands; and headaches.
     
  • Try vitamin B6, calcium, and magnesium supplements.
     
  • Now is a good time to take fish oil.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/06/2016

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header:
Let's see how to take care of this insect bite.

Know that we are talking about insect bites and stings that caused a mild reaction confined to the area of the bite.

If you are having a severe reaction to the insect bite, seek emergency room visit.

Since most insect bites cause itching and swelling, we will take a look at what is available over the counter to take care of this.

We will also figure out what to do in case there are other symptoms like pain or blisters.

With this in mind, use the search field below to search for an insect and see what is available over the counter to take care of the bites.

mode.1: Self-care recommendations for bedbugs bites are discussed below. But you must have pest control get rid of these bedbugs to be successful.
mode.2: Remedies available over-the-counter for bee stings are discussed below.
mode.3: Let's see how to take care of this black fly bites.
mode.4: Remedies for chigger bites available over-the-counter are discussed below.
mode.5:
Let's figure out how to take care of this fireants bites.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.6:
Let's find what to use over-the-counter for these flea bites.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.7: Over-the-counter recommendations for mosquito bites are discussed below.
mode.8:
Let's see what to use for insect bites over-the-counter.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.9:
Let's see how to take care of this moth irritation.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.10:
Let's see what to use over-the-counter for this spider bite.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.11:
Recommendations for tick bites available over-the-counter are discussed below.

 

Need treatment overview entry here
mode.12:
Let's see how to take care of this wasp bites over-the-counter.

 

Need treatment overview entry here

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/06/2016

collapsable.title: Anti-Itch click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Diphenhydramine

You will take the tablets to help with itching if the affected area is pretty large. If not a large area, the cream, roll-on or spray will do fine.

Calamine Lotion    ​

This is good as an anti-itch, antiseptic to prevent infection and astringent to dry up the affected spots.

Hydrocortisone 1%    

This is a steroidal cream that helps relieve itching and inflammation. Use this if the affected area is not large and dab it on the spots rather than rubbing all over the skin. You want to minimize the amount that the skin will absorb.

collapsable.title: Anti-inflammation click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Hydrocortisone 1%    

This will help both with the inflammation and itching of the affected area. Do not apply to a very large continuous  area. If the bedbugs bite area is large, you have to seek urgent care.

NSAIDs

Ibuprofen or naproxen will help if the bites are painful or very inflamed. 

Witch Hazel

Consider dabbing witch hazel on the affected areas if it is oozing. Probably use this before applying hydrocortisone cream or lotion.

collapsable.title: Worth Doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Must get pest control company to get rid of the bedbugs. Do not try to do this yourself. You won't be successful. DIY does not work here.

2. Vacuum mattress and box-spring crevices

3. Place beddings and clothes in the dryer for 20 minutes on medium to high heat.

4. Cover mattress and box springs with a mattress cover that is impermeable.

collapsable.title: Remove the Stinger click to expand contents
collapsable.content: This is the first step you have to take. It does not matter how you remove it, just do it. The earlier the better. A delay of a few seconds means more venom being injected.

collapsable.title: Pain Relief click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Cold Compress

Do this once the stinger has been removed. This will help reduce the inflammation or swelling. Keep applying ice until the pain has subsided. While doing this, have someone go to the pharmacy to get you benzocaine.

Benzocaine, Lidocaine

These are local anesthetics that will numb the area providing pain and itch relief. Look for Lanacaine, Solarcaine sprays. Or go to the pharmacy counter and ask for lidocaine gel/cream. Any percentage is adequate, but the higher the better. LMX is a good brand. If these are not available, apply Orajel or Anbesol used for a toothache if you have any at home.

collapsable.title: Inflammation click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Hydrocortisone 1%

This should help with the swelling, redness and itch. Use this after using ice to reduce the pain.

NSAIDs

Take aspirin to help with the inflammation if you can, especially to reduce the redness. Prefer aspirin over ibuprofen or naproxen but either should be fine.

collapsable.title: Anti-Itch click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Diphenhydramine

Take the tablets to help with the itch or prevent excessive itching. You will also take this to prevent any allergic reaction to the bee sting.

You may combine this hydrocortisone 1% cream or lotion for  inflammation that can cause redness, swelling and itching. 

You must not scratch the area.

collapsable.title: Anti-Itch click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Diphenhydramine

This is an antihistamine to relieve itching. Take the pills if affected area is all over the body

Hydrocortisone 1%

Good for both itching and inflammation

Witch Hazel

To help reduce inflammation

collapsable.title: For Itching click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Cold / Ice

Apply this to the affected area to start with.

2. Hydrocortisone 1%

Will help with the itching and inflammation

3. Capsaicin cream

4. Heat the bite with a hair dryer    

5. Add 2 tablespoonful salt in a jar of Vicks Vapor rub.

collapsable.title: Anti-Itch click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Hydrocortisone 1%

Apply this for both itching and to get rid of the swelling

Antihistamine

Take the tablets if the bites are all over the body. Diphenhydramine is a good example. The creams, sprays or lotions are better used if the bites just happened. These can prevent further release of histamine that causes the itching.

Calamine Lotion

This is useful to stop the itching and being an astringent, can reduce swelling.

Combination

Hydrocortisone 1% + Diphenhydramine (tablets or cream)

collapsable.title: For inflammation click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Cold Compress / Ice    ​

Use this as soon as possible to control any swelling.

Hydrocortisone 1%

Apply this to prevent or reduce swelling and redness of the affected area.

tabs.header_iregular:
Article currently being updated and reviewed by the pharmacist.
Please check back later.

This assumes you are looking at a minor skin rash.

A rash can be caused by many things. It is important you followed the link to appropriate topics suggested for you before you got to this stage.

For instance, if the rash is caused by a ringworm, you will need an antifungal cream, if due to poison ivy, there is a specific management process for that, if it is an allergic reaction, the best bet would be using an antihistamine cream or tablets. 

The rash that will be talked about here is something like a rash you got on contact with something or heat rash.

With this in mind, see what is recommended below to help with a skin rash.

collapsable.title: For Inflammation  click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Hydrocortisone 1%

This will help with the inflammation of the affected area. Use this for mild cases only as this cream does not penetrate deep into the skin and as such effectiveness is limited.

collapsable.title: For Whole Body Itch click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Itching all over the body?    

1. Diphenhydramine tablets
This is an antihistamine that will ease the itching. Will make you drowsy. If you need something less drowsy for daytime use, try chlorpheniramine.

2. Sarna lotion
This contains menthol(0.5%), camphor(0.5%) which are very good ingredients for itchy skin. It is also steroid free.

3. Calamine lotion
Combines anti-itch with antiseptic and astringent effect.

4. Oatmeal bath
Prefer if the skin is dry, itchy and irritated. Oatmeal can help restore the skin's natural pH, provide temporary skin protection and restore moisture to the skin.

We would rather you go to the store and get the colloidal oatmeal bath powder packets. Aveeno is a good brand. It would be hard to get a good effect if you make it on your own.   ​

collapsable.title: For Spotty Itch click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Hydrocortisone 1%
Steroidal anti-itch cream or lotion. Apply to affected area only.

Benzocaine, Lidocaine
Will temporarily numb the itchy area. It may cause skin sensitization so do not use in children.

Diphenhydramine cream, spray
More specific for itching. The rash will have to disappear on its own with time. If you have the cash, probably mix this with hydrocortisone 1%.

Cold compress
We recommend you start with this before applying any anti-itch cream or lotion

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/06/2016
